timeline.bodyText:
If you're going to mutate this map, then you need to copy it first in the constructor in case the map you were provided is unmodifiable.
Can you add a comment in code to say what this is doing?
timeline.author: mtdowling

timeline.bodyText: nit: extra blank line
timeline.author: mtdowling

timeline.bodyText: nit: extra blank line
timeline.author: mtdowling

timeline.bodyText:
nit: add opening

tags for each newline after the first.
timeline.author: mtdowling

timeline.bodyText:
nit: add

tags for each newline/paragraph after the first one
timeline.author: mtdowling

timeline.bodyText: Would love to see a comment to outline what's about to happen. "This transformer first converts the model to a Node using the JSON AST format. This approach was chosen because X."
timeline.author: mtdowling

timeline.bodyText: Using a ModelAssembler really needs the ability to specify a custom classloader (for loading things like traits).... or maybe we use a Supplier that creates ModelAssemblers. We did a similar thing in smithy-build. That should probably be an optional argument to this class and an overload in the ModelTransformer.
timeline.author: mtdowling

timeline.bodyText: nit: put each "." on a new line to make this easier to read
timeline.author: mtdowling

timeline.bodyText: nit: put a newline between test setup and test assertions
timeline.author: mtdowling

timeline.bodyText: nit: You don't need to specify the type parameters on the right hand side of this statement.
timeline.author: mtdowling

timeline.bodyText: nit: I would avoid using esoteric map features like this for readability. Just create a map, then put things in it on separate lines. It's actually fewer lines and more clear that way.
timeline.author: mtdowling

timeline.bodyText: Nit: this kind of setup typically would go in the constructor, but given the other suggestion to just require that one is passed in to the class, this can go away.
timeline.author: mtdowling

timeline.bodyText: Nit: for readability, you could assign the rewritten node to a variable then pass that variable into the addDocumentNode method.
timeline.author: mtdowling

timeline.bodyText: I suggest that you call the overloaded renameShapes method and pass in a default version of the supplier (e.g., Model::assembler).
timeline.author: mtdowling
mtdowling
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -132,6 +136,38 @@ public Model removeShapesIf(Model model, Predicate predicate) { return filterShapes(model, FunctionalUtils.not(predicate)); } + /** + * Renames shapes using ShapeId pairs while ensuring that the + * transformed model is in a consistent state. + * + *

This transformer ensures that when an aggregate shape is renamed, all + * members are updated in the model. + * + * @param model Model to transform. + * @param renamed Map of shapeIds + * @return Returns the transformed model.base. + */ + public Model renameShapes(Model model, Map renamed) { + return new RenameShapes(renamed).transform(this, model); + } + + /** + * Renames shapes using ShapeId pairs while ensuring that the + * transformed model is in a consistent state. + * + *

This transformer ensures that when an aggregate shape is renamed, all + * members are updated in the model. + * + * @param model Model to transform. + * @param renamed Map of shapeIds + * @param modelAssemblerSupplier Supplier used to create {@link ModelAssembler}s in each transform. + * @return Returns the transformed model.base. + */ + public Model renameShapes(Model model, Map renamed,

timeline.bodyText: nit: usually it's clearer (and consistent with the rest of our codebase) to just use a static import for Matchers.
timeline.author: mtdowling
